headline: Heard on the Street Recap: Anxiety in the Grocery Space
summary: Amazon plans a massive expansion of its grocery-delivery business, a move to boost growth in one of the few retail arenas in which it doesn’t yet have a dominant position.  Shares of grocery companies fell on the news of Amazon’s expansion, with Instacart-owner Maplebear sinking 12%, DoorDash down 3.8% and Kroger sliding 4.4%.

headline: US container imports may have peaked in July, chief of busiest seaport says
summary: LOS ANGELES (Reuters) -Ocean imports to the United States may have peaked in July after retailers raced to bring in goods from China and elsewhere to avoid potentially hefty tariffs on holiday-related products, logistics executives said on Wednesday.  Containerized imports to the Port of Los Angeles, the nation's busiest and a bellwether for U.S. trade, jumped 8% to 544,000 20-foot equivalent units (TEUs) in July from the same month of 2024.  "Much of this volume was fueled by importers hustling to bring in cargo ahead of potential tariff hikes later this month and beyond," Gene Seroka, the port's executive director, said on Wednesday.

raw.headline: US container imports may have peaked in July, chief of busiest seaport says
raw.summary: LOS ANGELES (Reuters) -Ocean imports to the United States may have peaked in July after retailers raced to bring in goods from China and elsewhere to avoid potentially hefty tariffs on holiday-related products, logistics executives said on Wednesday. "Much of this volume was fueled by importers hustling to bring in cargo ahead of potential tariff hikes later this month and beyond," Gene Seroka, the port's executive director, said on Wednesday.

headline: Walmart’s New Employee Perk Takes a Bite Out of Workers’ Grocery Bills
summary: Walmart’s  newest employee benefit takes aim at a growing cost for many of its workers: their grocery bills.  The country’s largest private employer said that, effective immediately, it was extending its 10% employee discount to include nearly all grocery purchases at its stores and online—its latest effort to better recruit and retain workers.  Walmart workers have grumbled about the perk’s limitations for years.

Walmart workers have grumbled about the perk’s limitations for years.

headline: Amazon boosts same-day delivery to take on Instacart, Walmart
summary: STORY: Amazon announced on Wednesday that it is expanding its grocery fast-delivery option for its Prime members to include perishable items like fruit, milk and frozen dinners.It's the latest move by Amazon to compete with grocery delivery services offered by Walmart and Instacart.Amazon’s stock rose as much as 1.5 percent in Wednesday morning trading while Walmart slipped as much as 2 and a half percent and Instacart plunged 12% at one point.Amazon shoppers in more than 1,000 U.S. cities, including Phoenix and Tampa, can already get doorstep delivery within hours of placing an order.Amazon plans to expand its fast-delivery service to 2,300 cities by the end of the year.The company announced in June it is investing $4 billion to bring same-day and next-day delivery services to more than 4,000 rural U.S. communities by the end of the year as well.Previously, Prime subscribers' grocery orders were fulfilled through Amazon Fresh or Whole Foods. Now the additional service will complete orders through its same-day delivery logistics locations.Prime members who pay about $15 a month or $149 a year will get this benefit for free for orders over $25 which is the minimum required for free delivery for Walmart+ members who pay $98 a year. Walmart said in May that it will soon be able to offer delivery within three hours to 95% of the U.S. population, and that faster delivery speeds are helping drive its business. Between February and April, Walmart reported a 91% increase in deliveries under three hours compared with the same period last year.One analyst told Reuters the move by Amazon to lower the minimum order to $25 directly threatens Instacart by enabling customers to use Amazon for quick, one-off purchases, which is a core part of Instacart's main appeal.

raw.headline: Amazon boosts same-day delivery to take on Instacart, Walmart
raw.summary: STORY: Amazon announced on Wednesday that it is expanding its grocery fast-delivery option for its Prime members to include perishable items like fruit, milk and frozen dinners.It's the latest move by Amazon to compete with grocery delivery services offered by Walmart and Instacart.Amazon’s stock rose as much as 1.5 percent in Wednesday morning trading while Walmart slipped as much as 2 and a half percent and Instacart plunged 12% at one point.Amazon shoppers in more than 1,000 U.S. cities, including Phoenix and Tampa, can already get doorstep delivery within hours of placing an order.Amazon plans to expand its fast-delivery service to 2,300 cities by the end of the year.The company announced in June it is investing $4 billion to bring same-day and next-day delivery services to more than 4,000 rural U.S. communities by the end of the year as well.Previously, Prime subscribers' grocery orders were fulfilled through Amazon Fresh or Whole Foods. Now the additional service will complete orders through its same-day delivery logistics locations.Prime members who pay about $15 a month or $149 a year will get this benefit for free for orders over $25 which is the minimum required for free delivery for Walmart+ members who pay $98 a year. Walmart said in May that it will soon be able to offer delivery within three hours to 95% of the U.S. population, and that faster delivery speeds are helping drive its business. Between February and April, Walmart reported a 91% increase in deliveries under three hours compared with the same period last year.One analyst told Reuters the move by Amazon to lower the minimum order to $25 directly threatens Instacart by enabling customers to use Amazon for quick, one-off purchases, which is a core part of Instacart's main appeal.

headline: Amazon to Offer Same-Day Groceries Delivery in 2,300 Cities
summary: Same-day grocery delivery is free for Amazon Prime subscribers on orders over $25 in most cities, it said.  Amazon has spent decades transforming the way people shop, letting them access a broad selection of products via the internet.  US shoppers spend $1 trillion annually on groceries at more than 45,000 supermarkets around the country, according to the grocery trade group FMI.

headline: Walmart broadens 10% staff discount to include most grocery products
summary: The discount, previously limited to fresh produce and general merchandise such as apparel, now extends to almost all food categories — including milk, meat, dry grocery, and seafood — in stores and online, effective immediately.  Walmart, the largest private employer in the United States, had previously extended its grocery discount during the holidays, but the perk will now be available year-round, the company said.  "We've heard your feedback that these savings make a real difference for you and your families," Donna Morris, Walmart’s chief people officer, wrote in the letter.

"We've heard your feedback that these savings make a real difference for you and your families," Donna Morris, Walmart’s chief people officer, wrote in the letter.

headline: AN Supps Expands Innovation With Iconic Chiquita® Brand Collab and a Nationwide Walmart U.S. Launch
summary: NASHVILLE, Tenn., August 13, 2025--With the indulgence of beach barbeques and happy hours fading into rear view mirrors, consumers will stock up on health and wellness related foods and beverages, while shopping for the Fall. AN Supps, a division of Applied Nutrition PLC, has responded to this trend - joining forces with Chiquita® Brands International and thousands of Walmart U.S. stores to deliver protein and pre-workout sports beverage mixes.

headline: Amazon expands its perishable delivery service, putting pressure on traditional grocers
summary: Amazon is now rolling out a service where its Prime members can order their blueberries and milk at the same time as their batteries and other basic items.  The online juggernaut said Wednesday that customers in more than 1,000 cities and towns now have access to fresh groceries with its free Same-Day Delivery on orders over $25 for Prime members, with plans to reach over 2,300 by the end of the year.  The company said that if an order doesn’t meet the minimum, members can still choose same-day delivery for a $2.99 fee.

The online juggernaut said Wednesday that customers in more than 1,000 cities and towns now have access to fresh groceries with its free Same-Day Delivery on orders over $25 for Prime members, with plans to reach over 2,300 by the end of the year.  The company said that if an order doesn’t meet the minimum, members can still choose same-day delivery for a $2.99 fee.

headline: Amazon expands same-day grocery delivery to perishable foods to compete with Instacart, Walmart
summary: NEW YORK (Reuters) -Subscribers to Amazon.com's Prime service can now receive strawberries, milk, meats and frozen dinners on the same day they order them as the company expands its fast-delivery option to perishable food items, Amazon announced on Wednesday.  It is the latest move by Amazon to compete with grocery delivery services offered by Walmart+ and Instacart.  Shoppers in more than 1,000 U.S. cities - including Phoenix; Raleigh, North Carolina; and Tampa, Florida - can get ice cream delivered to their doors within hours, while Amazon plans to expand the service to 2,300 cities by the end of the year.

It is the latest move by Amazon to compete with grocery delivery services offered by Walmart+ and Instacart.  Shoppers in more than 1,000 U.S. cities - including Phoenix; Raleigh, North Carolina; and Tampa, Florida - can get ice cream delivered to their doors within hours, while Amazon plans to expand the service to 2,300 cities by the end of the year.
